case_title: COMMISSIONER OF INCOME-TAX vs MARGADARSI CHIT FUND (P.) LTD.
complaint_summary: The Revenue challenged the Tribunal's decision allowing depreciation under Section 32 of the Income-tax Act for bottles leased out as business assets.
investigation_summary: The Tribunal relied on the precedent set in CIT v. Sri Krishna Bottlers (Pvt.) Ltd. (1989) 175 ITR 154, which classified bottles as 'plant' under Section 32(1) of the Income-tax Act.
judgment_summary: The court upheld the Tribunal's decision, confirming that bottles leased out for business purposes qualify as 'plant' under Section 32(1) of the Income-tax Act, and depreciation is allowable irrespective of bulk or individual purchase.
legal_arguments: Prosecution argued that depreciation should only apply to bulk purchases exceeding Rs. 5,000.
Defense relied on the precedent set in CIT v. Sri Krishna Bottlers (Pvt.) Ltd., which classified bottles as 'plant' eligible for depreciation.
assets: Bottles leased out for business purposes
citations: CIT v. Sri Krishna Bottlers (Pvt.) Ltd. (1989) 175 ITR 154
key_issues: Whether bottles leased out for business purposes qualify as 'plant' under Section 32(1) of the Income-tax Act.
Whether depreciation is allowable for individual items priced below Rs. 5,000.

legal_issues.issue: Whether the Tribunal was correct in allowing deduction under Section 32 of the Income-tax Act for bottles leased out as a business.

key_arguments.argument: Depreciation under Section 32(1) is allowable only for bulk purchases and not for single items priced below Rs. 5,000.
Bottles used in the business qualify as 'plant' under Section 32(1) and are eligible for depreciation.

key_precedents.case_name: CIT v. Sri Krishna Bottlers (Pvt.) Ltd.
key_precedents.holding: Bottles used in business are considered 'plant' and eligible for 100% depreciation.

statutes_referenced.description: Allows depreciation on buildings, machinery, plant, or furniture used for business or profession.
Allows full deduction for machinery or plant costing less than Rs. 5,000 in the year it is first used.

court_observations: Bottles leased out as part of the respondent's business qualify as 'plant' under Section 32(1).
No distinction exists between bulk purchases and individual purchases for depreciation purposes.
Depreciation can be claimed if the item is integrally involved in the business.
final_decision: The Tribunal's decision was upheld, and the petition was dismissed.

legal_terms.Plant: An asset used for business purposes that qualifies for depreciation under tax law.

words_and_phrases.Depreciation: Reduction in the value of an asset over time.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the classification of bottles as 'plant' under Section 32(1) of the Income-tax Act for depreciation purposes. The court upheld the Tribunal's decision, dismissing the Revenue's petition and confirming that depreciation is allowable irrespective of bulk or individual purchase.
